claim: The author structures the narrative around internal reflection and character introspection.
evidence: In the story regarding "a Londoner missing an island and Camille," the protagonist's internal monologue reveals his gradual realization of what he misses, as he reflects, "Although at the same time… something is missing, and he just can’t put his finger on it, which frustrates him because it’s basically his job to do just that."

claim: The author creatively uses humor and irony to reinterpret the prompt.
evidence: In the story regarding "a Londoner missing an island and Camille," the protagonist humorously notes, "there is finally proper tea around every corner, as opposed to just one place on an entire island that serves it (not that he would ever say so out loud on Saint Marie, Catherine must never know)."

claim: The author develops characters through internal conflicts, familial interactions, and introspection.
evidence: In the story regarding "a Londoner missing an island and Camille," the protagonist's relationship with his mother is explored through dialogue and introspection, as seen when she observes, "I saw your eyes light up," prompting him to reflect on his feelings for Camille.

claim: The author employs a conversational and introspective tone to convey the protagonist's internal conflict.
evidence: In the story regarding "a Londoner missing an island and Camille," the protagonist's thoughts are presented in a conversational manner, such as when he muses, "He’ll figure it out eventually, he tells himself, because he always does. He doesn’t mention it to anyone, of course, because it is ridiculous."
